outputValidation.content:
{
  "problem_id": "P03",
  "final_answer": {
    "value": 0.0702,
    "units": "mol dm-3",
    "precision_note": "Reported to 3 significant figures (limited by 0.150 mol dm-3 and titre data)."
  },
  "method": "Convert the NaOH titre to dm3: 23.40 cm3 = 0.02340 dm3. Use c = n/V rearranged to n = cV: n(NaOH)=0.150×0.02340=0.00351 mol. From H2SO4 + 2NaOH -> Na2SO4 + 2H2O, 2 mol NaOH neutralize 1 mol H2SO4, so n(H2SO4)=0.00351/2=0.001755 mol. The acid volume is 25.00 cm3 = 0.02500 dm3, therefore c(H2SO4)=n/V=0.001755/0.02500=0.0702 mol dm-3.",
  "key_equations": [
    "c = n / V",
    "n = c×V",
    "n(H2SO4) = n(NaOH)/2"
  ],
  "line_refs": [
    "L15",
    "L39",
    "L40",
    "L41"
  ],
  "checks": [
    "If acid were 0.070 mol dm-3, moles in 0.0250 dm3 is ~0.00175 mol, matching stoichiometry from NaOH.",
    "Concentration is lower than NaOH concentration, as expected because NaOH volume is similar but 2:1 base:acid ratio."
  ]
}

{
  "problem_id": "P05",
  "final_answer": {
    "value": 0.889,
    "units": "g",
    "precision_note": "Reported to 3 significant figures based on current (1.50 A) and time (30.0 min) data."
  },
  "method": "Convert time to seconds: 30.0 min × 60 = 1800 s. Charge passed Q = I×t = 1.50×1800 = 2700 C. Using Faraday constant F = 96,500 C mol-1, moles of electrons passed is n(e−)=Q/F=2700/96500=0.02798 mol. From Cu2+ + 2e− -> Cu, 2 mol e− deposit 1 mol Cu, so n(Cu)=0.02798/2=0.01399 mol. Using Ar(Cu)=63.55 g mol-1, mass deposited m = n×Ar = 0.01399×63.55 = 0.889 g.",
  "key_equations": [
    "Q = I×t",
    "n(e-) = Q/F",
    "m = n×Mr"
  ],
  "line_refs": [
    "L24",
    "L51",
    "L52",
    "L19"
  ],
  "checks": [
    "Order-of-magnitude: 2700 C is ~0.028 mol e−, so Cu moles ~0.014 mol giving < 1 g Cu; result 0.889 g fits.",
    "Stoichiometry check: dividing electron moles by 2 matches the 2e− in the given half-equation."
  ]
}
